anomalies.message: [REJECT] Written amount contains multiple spelling errors (“FOUN” instead of “FOUR”, “FISTY” instead of “FIFTY”), indicating document tampering.
Written amount spelling errors (“FOUN” vs “FOUR”, “FISTY” vs “FIFTY”)

raw_text:
MoneyGram
PAY TO: SARAH CHEN
MONEYGRAM
MONEY ORDER
AMOUNT: $450.00
FOUN HUNDRED FISTY AND 00//100 DOLLARS
FROM: MICHAEL LEE
456 PINE ST, ANYTOWN, CA 91234
9835647821
9021056789

Michael Lee
AGENT AUTHORIZED SIGNATURE

ai_analysis.summary: Written amount contains multiple spelling errors (“FOUN” instead of “FOUR”, “FISTY” instead of “FIFTY”), indicating document tampering.
reasoning: Raw OCR text shows “FOUN HUNDRED FISTY AND 00//100 DOLLARS,” demonstrating clear misspellings in the written amount.
Training data indicates 45% of fraud cases involve amount mismatches or tampering; spelling errors are even stronger evidence.
ML model scored this order as very low risk, but the hard rule on amount spelling overrides ML output.
Customer has no history of fraud, but spelling errors on a professionally printed money order are highly suspicious.
key_indicators: Written amount spelling errors (“FOUN” vs “FOUR”, “FISTY” vs “FIFTY”)
actionable_recommendations: Contact MoneyGram to verify the serial number and printed amount format.
Request the purchaser provide a replacement money order with correct printed wording.
Inspect future transactions for proper printed amount spelling before acceptance.

reasons: Raw OCR shows “FOUN HUNDRED FISTY…” instead of “FOUR HUNDRED FIFTY…,” indicating printed or manual alteration.
Spelling errors in professionally printed fields are a strong tampering indicator.
